items.title: Can't install on macOS with Apple-provided Python 3
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Installation through pip3 on macOS fails on `Bottleneck-1.3.2` installation.

I also noticed many IBM AIX-related messages when this is macOS.

**To Reproduce**
Install Apple's Python 3 (part of Xcode command line tools) with command `xcode-select --install`.
I can't use that bloatware called Anaconda.

Then try to install Bottleneck with:

`pip3 install Bottleneck --user`

I usually don't have problems installing other Python packages with same method, including those that need compiling.

Apparently the error bellow is related to lack of permissions to install on `/Library/Python/3.7` which doesn't make sense since I'm using `--user` to avoid system folders. Which makes it still a module bug.

items.title: [RFC] NEP 29 adoption (drop <3.6 in next release)
items.body:
With Python 2 reaching EOL on 1/1/2020, `bottleneck` will also be dropping support for Python 2.7.

With the recent adoption of NEP 29, `numpy` has adopted a formal version upgrade cadence. Given `bottleneck`'s tight compatibility with `numpy`, it likely makes sense for us to adopt NEP 29 as well. The relevant section is the following timeline:
```
Date | Python | NumPy
Jan 07, 2020 | 3.6+ | 1.15+
Jun 23, 2020 | 3.7+ | 1.15+
Jul 23, 2020 | 3.7+ | 1.16+
Jan 13, 2021 | 3.7+ | 1.17+
Jul 26, 2021 | 3.7+ | 1.18+
Dec 26, 2021 | 3.8+ | 1.18+
Apr 14, 2023 | 3.9+ | 1.18+
```
This would imply dropping 3.5 support in the next release as well. We would not be doing anything to actively inhibit use on 3.5, just not actively testing or seeking to fix issues that solely exhibit there.

Please reach out in this thread if this would inhibit your use of `bottleneck`. If there is no general objection, I will adopt NEP 29 around 1/1/2020.

items.title: Memory leak in 1.3.0
items.body:
We upgraded to 1.3.0 but had to rollback to 1.2.1 because there's a memory leak. It was pretty easy to observe as all our data processing containers would go consistently OOM with this release after about a half hour vs having tightly constrained memory in the previous release.

It's hard to track down exactly where as the code in question is using a mix of 
nansum,nanargmax,nanargmin,nanmedian,nansum,nanmean,nanmin,nanmax,nanvar,nanmedian.

But I want to make sure this gets filed as there is something lurking here that could bite others as well.

items.title: Error running with python3
items.body:
We are getting runtime error with python 3.6.4 and bottlenext 1.2.1. Simple tests fails [a]
```
import bottleneck
bottleneck.bench()
```
Looks like https://github.com/pydata/bottleneck/blob/master/bottleneck/benchmark/autotimeit.py#L6 is passing a float which python3 did not like.

[a]

items.title: Future of bottleneck
items.body: Due to health problems, I can no longer maintain bottleneck. I hope that bottleneck is forked and a dominant fork emerges. Thanks to all who have reported issues and made PRs or just stopped by to say hello.

items.title: Py2 Support
items.body: Can we open discussion on a py2 fix. Currently install_requires has numpy version open. This version 1.2.1 is stated to support py2. numpy 1.17 drops support for py2. Recent install are trying to grab numpy 1.17.rcX

items.title: Some odd build output
items.body:
When I run `make build` I observe some extremely odd output:
[build.log](https://github.com/kwgoodman/bottleneck/files/3123962/build.log)

1) I assume that `aj == aj` warning is just a `NaN` check? 
2) I've never seen such a weird (read - messy) combination of compiler flags. Where does it come from?

items.title: pandas import errors with current bottleneck pip wheel
items.body:
```
conda create --name bottleneck python=3.7
conda activate bottleneck
pip install pandas bottleneck
Successfully installed bottleneck-1.2.1 numpy-1.15.4 pandas-0.23.4 python-dateutil-2.7.5 pytz-2018.9 six-1.12.0
```
then:
```
python -c "import pandas"
```
gives:
```
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'numpy.core._multiarray_umath'
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'numpy.core._multiarray_umath'
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'numpy.core._multiarray_umath'
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'numpy.core._multiarray_umath'
```
In the example, the error is not fatal, in normal settings, but in some settings it leads to a fatal error.

Different workarounds:

1. `conda install bottleneck numpy` (instead of pip)
2. pip install bottleneck from source 
```
pip install git+https://github.com/kwgoodman/bottleneck/commit/104778a8dea49d0ca230288b5011c17979c4ac99
```
3. `pip install numpy==1.16.0rc1`

There are quite a few of these reports on [google](https://www.google.com/search?q=ModuleNotFoundError%3A+No+module+named+%22numpy.core._multiarray_umath%22)

items.title: Leaks memory when input is not a numpy array
items.body:
If you run the following program you see that `nansum` leaks all the memory it are given when passed a Pandas object. If it is passed the ndarray underlying the Pandas object instead then there is no leak:

```
import psutil
import gc

def f():
    x = np.zeros(10*1024*1024, dtype='f4')

    # Leaks 40MB/iteration
    bottleneck.nansum(pd.Series(x))
    # No leak:
    #bottleneck.nansum(x)

process = psutil.Process(os.getpid())

def _get_usage():
    gc.collect()
    return process.memory_info().private / (1024*1024)

last_usage = _get_usage()
print(last_usage)

for _ in range(10):
    f()
    usage = _get_usage()
    print(usage - last_usage)
    last_usage = usage
```

This affects not just `nansum`, but apparently all the reduction functions (with or without `axis` specified), and at least some other functions like `move_max`.

I'm not completely sure why this happens, but maybe it's because `PyArray_FROM_O` is allocating a new array in this case, and the ref count of that is not being decremented by anyone? https://github.com/kwgoodman/bottleneck/blob/master/bottleneck/src/reduce_template.c#L1237

I'm using Bottleneck 1.2.1 with Pandas 0.23.1. `sys.version` is `3.6.1 (v3.6.1:69c0db5, Mar 21 2017, 18:41:36) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)]`.

items.title: New release?
items.body:
I notice that bottleneck's last release was about 18 months ago, in May 2017.

If it's not too much trouble, it would be nice to a see an incremental release with the few fixes that have made it in since then.

items.title: Speed up anynan for float32 and float64 using isunordered
items.body:
The C function `isunordered(x, y)` returns 1 if either argument is NAN.  This can be used to check two values per `anynan()` loop iteration instead of one.

How to implement this is not so clear to me due to the [macros involved](https://github.com/kwgoodman/bottleneck/blob/f783ce7a53a3375cd5c3e5c943c098b21254eb96/bottleneck/src/reduce_template.c#L948), but I did verify that `anynan_all_float64()` generates code using `ucomisd %xmm0 %xmm0`.  If bottleneck would "unroll" the loop 2x by calling `isunordered()`, the generated code should be `ucomisd %xmm0 %xmm1` or similar, and the loop iterations would be cut in half.

items.title: bn.nansum on array with np.newaxis added dimension
items.body:
Bottleneck's nansum (and nanmean, etc) doesn't seem to give the right answer when dimensions are added with np.newaxis. An example is:

In [27]: a = np.ones((2,2))

In [28]: a[1, :] = np.nan

In [29]: bn.nansum(a) # Correct
Out[29]: 2.0

In [30]: bn.nansum(a[..., np.newaxis])  # **Wrong**
Out[30]: 4.0

In [31]: np.nansum(a[..., np.newaxis])  # numpy does the right thing.
Out[31]: 2.0

In [32]: np.__version__
Out[32]: '1.12.1'

In [33]: bn.__version__
Out[33]: '1.2.1'

items.title: RuntimeError with numpy==1.13 and pandas==0.21.1
items.body:
Wasn't super sure as to whether to post this here or on the downstream pandas repository since I'm not sure where the issue originates, but I think it might be here.  Basically, I updated all my packages and found that pandas was spitting out errors (but continues). After a bunch of installing / uninstalling and binary searching through my requirements files, I found that removing bottleneck removes the issue. Perhaps this is a compatibility problem - has numpy changed a critical API?

```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
RuntimeError                              Traceback (most recent call last)
RuntimeError: module compiled against API version 0xc but this version of numpy is 0xb
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
RuntimeError                              Traceback (most recent call last)
RuntimeError: module compiled against API version 0xc but this version of numpy is 0xb
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
RuntimeError                              Traceback (most recent call last)
RuntimeError: module compiled against API version 0xc but this version of numpy is 0xb
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
RuntimeError                              Traceback (most recent call last)
RuntimeError: module compiled against API version 0xc but this version of numpy is 0xb
```

Steps:

1. `python3 -mvenv env`
2. `. env/bin/activate`
3. `pip install "numpy==1.13 pandas==0.21.1`
4. Import pandas and see that it works
5. `pip install bottleneck`
6. Import pandas and see above errors.

items.title: bn.nansum on boolean array
items.body:
Is this behavior expected?

```python
In [1]: import numpy as np

In [2]: import bottleneck as bn

In [3]: arr = np.array([True, True, False])

In [4]: np.nansum(arr)  # cast from bool -> int
Out[4]: 2

In [5]: bn.nansum(arr)  # no upcasting
Out[5]: True
```

I'm not sure what bottleneck's goals are are w.r.t upcasting output types.

items.title: Error when passing in a default to bn.push
items.body:
Bottleneck doesn't seem to be well behaved if you _pass in_ default values for `bn.push`:

Default states `n=None` (and works with no value):

python
```
In [1]: import bottleneck as bn

In [4]: import numpy as np

In [5]: a=np.array([1,2,3,4])

In [7]: bn.push(a)
Out[7]: array([1, 2, 3, 4])

In [8]: bn.push?
Docstring:
push(a, n=None, axis=-1)
...
n : {int, None}, optional
```

but when you pass in `None`, it raises:
```
In [9]: bn.push(a, n=None)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-9-d7ea6fc52366> in <module>()
----> 1 bn.push(a, n=None)

TypeError: `n` must be an integer
```

This is only really impactful when building a function that uses `bottleneck`, (which we're increasingly doing in `xarray`)

items.title: License lists full history of Python licenses instead of relevant PSF license.
items.body: Under setuptools in your license, you list, correctly, that setuptools is dual-licensed. Then, you copy and paste in both licenses. But instead of copying the PSF license, it appears you copied the entire history of licenses that python has used in the past, and which pieces of python use, as seen here https://docs.python.org/3/license.html. I believe that setuptools' license specifically refers to the PSF license, and does not invoke every license in Python's history.

items.title: Drop the vendored copy of numpydoc
items.body: Please consider dropping the vendored copy of `numpydoc` in favor of adding an `extra_requires` to your setuptools metadata.

items.title: Spurious .pyc files in release tarball
items.body:
Please thoroughly check your release tarballs before uploading. The latest version `1.2.1` contains spurious `.pyc` files under `doc/sphinxext`. You might want to update your `MANIFEST.in` to prune these systematically, specially if you aren't generating your tarballs from a clean environment.

Also, I am not sure the content of the `tools/` folder is really that useful for the release tarball, since it is mostly CI stuff.

Thanks,
Ghis

items.title: Preparing to release bottleneck 1.2.1
items.body:
I am getting ready to release bottleneck 1.2.1. This release adds support for NumPy's relaxed strides checking and fixes a few bugs. The only thing left to do is testing.

If you guys (@cgohlke windows, @shoyer xarray and pandas, @toobaz debian) have time please test.

Everyone else, please send in test reports. Does bn.test() pass on your computer? Does bn 1.2.1 (the master branch) run with your code that uses bn?

items.title: Relaxed stride checking in numpy 1.12 causes bottleneck unit test failures
items.body:
Hi, this is what reproduces the problem on my machine (linux mint):

```python
In [1]: import numpy as np

In [2]: import bottleneck as bn

In [3]: print('numpy:', np.__version__)
numpy: 1.12.0

In [4]: print('bottleneck:', bn.__version__)
bottleneck: 1.2.0

In [5]: a = np.ones((3, 2))

In [6]: np.sum(a[:, [1]]), bn.nansum(a[:, [1]])
Out[6]: (3.0, 1.0)

In [7]: np.sum(a[:, [1]].copy()), bn.nansum(a[:, [1]].copy())
Out[7]: (3.0, 3.0)
```

This has been hitting the [xarray test suite on debian](https://github.com/pydata/xarray/issues/1208). 

Thanks!

items.title: Py_DECREF in iterators.h
items.body:
I'm looking at `iterators.h` and it seems to me that the `Py_DECREF` calls might be misplaced. If I'm reading this right, it looks like the intent is to decref the result of the `PyArray_Ravel` calls, but the decref happens before `a` is done being accessed. I could be missing something though, since I'm not super familiar with the numpy C API.

[Example](https://github.com/kwgoodman/bottleneck/blob/e987847285edd514411667f28c0ebc808d7d2b21/bottleneck/src/iterators.h#L114)

items.title: Compiling on Ubuntu 12.04
items.body:
I ran into a surprising issue when compiling bottleneck on Ubuntu 12.04.  Specifically, the problem seems to arise when there is one version of numpy installed in the system folders (for example, the one that ships with Ubuntu), but I override it by having a more recent version of numpy installed in my user folder (e.g. by installing numpy with the --user option of pip).

The problem seems to be that the python include folders include a link to the numpy include folder (which refers to the older version of numpy shipped with Ubuntu).   I was able to work around the problem by changing setup.py to do
self.include_dirs.insert(0, numpy.get_include())
instead of 
self.include.append(numpy.get_include())

This was based on some searching that led me to this commit in another project:
https://github.com/TRIQS/triqs/commit/d86c0df332874f71f3e82300b185d4a0d41e6831

Assuming this change is generally harmless (which i would imagine it is), then maybe setup.py can be changed moving forward?

Thanks very much for a great project!

items.title: Making bottleneck faster
items.body:
I plan to experiment with ways to make bottleneck faster by using techniques like manual loop unrolling, software prefetching of data, SIMD, and parallel processing. Come join the fun! The playground is here: https://github.com/kwgoodman/some_sums.

This issue thread supersedes #117, #118, #122, #124.

After many years of use, just noticed this: On 64-bit systems, I typically use 32-bit data structures. A argpartsort on a 32-bit numpy array returned 64-bit integers.

Should the results be of the same cast as the data object being argpartsort'ed?

items.title: bug: wrong number of arguments
items.body:
This works:

```
In [1]: a = np.array([1, 2, 3])
In [2]: bn.nansum2(a, 0)
Out[2]: 6
```

This doesn't work in the `c_rewrite` branch:

```
In [3]: from numpy.testing import assert_raises
In [4]: assert_raises(ValueError, bn.nansum2, a, 0)
<snip>
TypeError: wrong number of arguments
```

In the first case kwargs is NULL and in the second case it is an empty dictionary. Adding this line to all the parsing functions should fix it:

```
const Py_ssize_t nkwds = kwds == NULL ? 0 : PyDict_Size(kwds);
```

items.title: Change all the raise macros
items.body:
Change all the raise macros from

```
#define VALUE_ERR(text)  PyErr_SetString(PyExc_ValueError, text)
```

to

```
#define VALUE_ERR(text)  PyErr_SetString(PyExc_ValueError, text); return NULL;
```

items.title: Rename ss, partsort, and argpartsort?
items.body:
`ss` is now called `sum_of_squares` in scipy. Bottleneck should probably change the name as well.

Bottleneck's `partsort` and `argpartsort` were created before numpy had `partition` and `argpartition`. We should probably change those names as well. We'd also have to change the signature:

```
bn.partsort(arr, n, axis) == np.partition(arr, n - 1, axis)
```

Good idea?

items.title: I'm considering switching to the GPL
items.body:
I prefer the GPL. I originally went with the BSD license because I saw that most numpy-based projects did so.

Recently I have spent a lot of time with bottleneck. Bottleneck 1.0 was a complete rewrite and bottleneck 1.2 will also be a complete rewrite. So I have had a chance to revisit most every decision I have ever made about bottleneck.

I know licensing can be contentious. So I thought I'd ask for comments before deciding (and before looking into whether I can legally make the change).

items.title: consider splitting memory allocation and computation functions in the c_rewrite branch
items.body:
e.g. see: https://github.com/kwgoodman/bottleneck/blob/6a4a315f7c5426b8071903697e5e65e27d0c905d/bottleneck/src/move2_template.c#L27 

If the split happens now, it will make it easy to parallelize these functions later.  Also, it makes it easy to benchmark the computation part only, as you can avoid repeated memory allocation.

items.title: Preparing to release bottleneck 1.1.0
Should we port bottleneck to C?
items.body:
I'm trying to port nansum to C (without using cython) to get a feel for how bottleneck would look written in pure C.

What I have so far (in the c_rewrite branch) is a nansum with reduced features that compiles but does not work at all. I have not yet tried to deal with reference counting because I don't yet know how. Any help, comments, appreciated.

Here's a demo on how to compile:

```
/bottleneck/bottleneck/template (c_rewrite)$ python setup.py build_ext --inplace
running build_ext
building 'nansum' extension
<snip>
In [1]: from nansum import nansum
In [2]: a=np.random.rand(4)
In [3]: nansum(a)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
SystemError                               Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-3-1d96a990bfd9> in <module>()
----> 1 nansum(a)

SystemError: error return without exception set
```

items.title: Speed up of reduce all
items.body:
I started working on speeding up reductions along a single, non-fast axis (issue #124) but instead ended up speeding up the case where you want to reduce along all axes.

Here's a demo. nansum is the same as in master; nansum2 is in the reduce_all branch.

Big improvement in function call overhead for 1d and 2d arrays:

```
In [1]: from bottleneck import nansum, nansum2

In [2]: a=np.random.rand(4)
In [3]: timeit nansum(a)
10000000 loops, best of 3: 194 ns per loop
In [4]: timeit nansum2(a)
10000000 loops, best of 3: 71.4 ns per loop

In [5]: a=np.random.rand(4,4)
In [6]: timeit nansum(a)
1000000 loops, best of 3: 229 ns per loop
In [7]: timeit nansum2(a)
10000000 loops, best of 3: 82.2 ns per loop
```

I expected the function call overhead to be a little worse for ndim > 2. But I did not see that. I'd have to look a bit more closely at the diff to figure that out:

```
In [8]: a=np.random.rand(2,2,2)
In [9]: timeit nansum(a)
1000000 loops, best of 3: 225 ns per loop
In [10]: timeit nansum2(a)
1000000 loops, best of 3: 193 ns per loop
```

Here's a nice one:

```
In [13]: a=np.random.rand(1000000,2)
In [14]: timeit nansum(a)
100 loops, best of 3: 3.25 ms per loop
In [15]: timeit nansum2(a)
1000 loops, best of 3: 1.67 ms per loop
```

What did I do? I special cased for 1d and 2d input arrays. Now neither one uses numpy iterators. In the example above it doesn't take long to add the two numbers in each row. What takes a long time (relative to adding two numbers) is PyArray_ITER_NEXT. That explains the performance in the example above. When using iterators it may be faster to sum along an axis that doesn't have the shortest stride.

The reason for the low overhead is that it takes a while (relative to adding a few numbers) to set up the iterator.

I think I can also special case for reduction along all axes for any ndim when the input array is single-segment.

This branch adds the first non-C ordered array unit tests in bottleneck. I'd like to come up with some more examples of arrays with strange memory layouts to make sure this works. How do I make a non-aligned array?

items.title: Where should we host the sphinx manual?
items.body: I'd like to move the sphinx manual. Where should we host it? Github? Readthedocs?

items.title: Speed up reduction along non fast axes
items.body:
For the C ordered array below Numpy is just as fast along axis 0 as it is along axis 1. Bottleneck is slow along axis 0.

```
In [1]: a = np.random.rand(1000, 10000)
In [2]: timeit np.nansum(a, 1)
10 loops, best of 3: 24.3 ms per loop
In [3]: timeit bn.nansum(a, 1)
100 loops, best of 3: 7.88 ms per loop
In [4]: timeit np.nansum(a, 0)
10 loops, best of 3: 24.8 ms per loop
In [5]: timeit bn.nansum(a, 0)
100 loops, best of 3: 16.1 ms per loop
```

I don't know how Numpy does it. But I imagine bottleneck could sum more than one column at a time using a temp C array. So instead of an `asum` variable we'd have an `asum[]` array and move along the fast axis (here axis 1) before advancing the slow axis (0).

Not sure how difficult it would be to implement.

items.title: Proposal for new design of bottleneck internals
items.body:
In the current design we do this to add the function bn.nanmean to bottleneck (I'll only show the float version, you'd also need to add the integer version):

```

@cython.cdivision(True)
cdef object nanmean_all_DTYPE0(np.flatiter ita, Py_ssize_t stride,
                               Py_ssize_t length, int int_input):
    # bn.dtypes = [['float64'], ['float32']]
    cdef Py_ssize_t i, count = 0
    cdef DTYPE0_t asum = 0, ai
    with nogil:
        while PyArray_ITER_NOTDONE(ita):
            for i in range(length):
                ai = (<DTYPE0_t*>((<char*>pid(ita)) + i * stride))[0]
                if ai == ai:
                    asum += ai
                    count += 1
            PyArray_ITER_NEXT(ita)
    if count > 0:
        return asum / count
    else:
        return NAN

@cython.cdivision(True)
cdef ndarray nanmean_one_DTYPE0(np.flatiter ita,
                                Py_ssize_t stride, Py_ssize_t length,
                                int a_ndim, np.npy_intp* y_dims,
                                int int_input):
    # bn.dtypes = [['float64'], ['float32']]
    cdef Py_ssize_t i, count
    cdef DTYPE0_t asum = 0, ai
    cdef ndarray y = PyArray_EMPTY(a_ndim - 1, y_dims, NPY_DTYPE0, 0)
    cdef np.flatiter ity = PyArray_IterNew(y)
    with nogil:
        if length == 0:
            while PyArray_ITER_NOTDONE(ity):
                (<DTYPE0_t*>((<char*>pid(ity))))[0] = NAN
                PyArray_ITER_NEXT(ity)
        else:
            while PyArray_ITER_NOTDONE(ita):
                asum = 0
                count = 0
                for i in range(length):
                    ai = (<DTYPE0_t*>((<char*>pid(ita)) + i*stride))[0]
                    if ai == ai:
                        asum += ai
                        count += 1
                if count > 0:
                    asum = asum / count
                else:
                    asum = NAN
                (<DTYPE0_t*>((<char*>pid(ity))))[0] = asum
                PyArray_ITER_NEXT(ita)
                PyArray_ITER_NEXT(ity)
    return y
```

Under the new proposal here's the code you'd write instead:

```
@cython.cdivision(True)
cdef inline DTYPE0_t nanmean_DTYPE0(char *p,
                                    Py_ssize_t stride,
                                    Py_ssize_t length,
                                    int int_input) nogil:
    # bn.dtypes = [['float64'], ['float32']]
    cdef Py_ssize_t i, count = 0
    cdef DTYPE0_t ai, asum = 0
    for i in range(length):
        ai = (<DTYPE0_t*>(p + i * stride))[0]
        if ai == ai:
            asum += ai
            count += 1
    if count > 0:
        return asum / count
    else:
        return NAN
```

The code is in the `minty_fresh` branch. I only ported nansum and nanmean (called nansum2 and nanmean2 in the branch).

When the length of each dimension of the array is large, performance is the same as before:

```
In [1]: a=np.random.rand(1000, 10000)
In [2]: timeit bn.nanmean(a)
100 loops, best of 3: 7.89 ms per loop
In [3]: timeit bn.nanmean2(a)
100 loops, best of 3: 7.86 ms per loop
```

For 1d arrays the overhead has been reduced:

```
In [4]: a=np.random.rand(10)
In [5]: timeit bn.nanmean(a)
1000000 loops, best of 3: 226 ns per loop
In [6]: timeit bn.nanmean2(a)
10000000 loops, best of 3: 184 ns per loop
```

For reduction of 2d (or higher) arrays with `axis=None`, overhead has increased because the rewrite uses PyArray_Ravel:

```
In [7]: a=np.random.rand(10,10)
In [8]: timeit bn.nanmean(a)
1000000 loops, best of 3: 325 ns per loop
In [9]: timeit bn.nanmean2(a)
1000000 loops, best of 3: 382 ns per loop
```

For repeated calls to the new inline function where each call does hardly any work, performance has decreased (not sure why; I don't even know if the inlining is taking place):

```
In [10]: a=np.random.rand(1000000,2)
In [11]: timeit bn.nanmean(a, 1)
100 loops, best of 3: 5.28 ms per loop
In [12]: timeit bn.nanmean2(a, 1)
100 loops, best of 3: 5.96 ms per loop
```

Adding a new reduction function to bottleneck is rare. So I'd only want to use the new design if we can improve the performance of the last two cases. On the other hand maybe the new design would make it easier to do things like optimize for reduction along a non-fast axis.

With float64:

items.title: bn.move_median seg fault
items.body:
The following causes a seg fault:

```
In [1]: a = np.array([1, 2, np.inf, 3, 4, 5])
In [2]: bn.move_median(a, window=3)
Segmentation fault
```

If the location of np.inf or the window size is changed then the function does not seg fault.

move_median.c uses C's INFINITY to mark missing values in the heaps. I assume that is the problem. If I replace INFINITY with DBL_MAX (from float.h) and replace C's isinf with

```
inline int myisinf(double val)
{
    if (val == DBL_MAX || val == -DBL_MAX){return 1;}
    return 0;
}
```

then the seg fault disappears. However a new seg faults appears:

```
In [1]: m=np.finfo(np.float64).max
In [2]: a=np.array([m,m,m,m,m,m,m,m,m])
In [3]: bn.move_median(a, window=3)
Segmentation fault
```

So I traded one problem for another.

I'm not familiar with move_median.c. @jennolsen84 do you have any ideas on what to do?

items.title: Why is bottleneck not merged into NumPy?
items.body:
In the documentation and also searching the internet I didn't find any hint on why Bottleneck functions are so much faster than standard NumPy ones and if there is any plan to merge the more efficient versions into NumPy proper.

As a user I was quite surprised to learn that I needed a special package to have the efficient version of such basic operations. I guess there is a good reason and maybe a short paragraph in the README may be enough to clear the confusion.

items.title: Broken top_level.txt file in distribution 1.0.0
items.body:
This is what the [setuptools documentation](https://pythonhosted.org/setuptools/formats.html#top-level-txt-conflict-management-metadata) says about the `top_level.txt`file:

> This file is a list of the top-level module or package names provided by the project, one Python identifier per line.
> 
> Subpackages are not included; a project containing both a `foo.bar` and a `foo.baz` would include only one line, `foo`, in its `top_level.txt`.

The file distributed with Bottleneck 1.0.0 can be accessed with:

```
>>> import pkg_resources
>>> provider = pkg_resources.get_distribution('Bottleneck')
>>> print(provider.get_metadata('top_level.txt'))
bottleneck
bottleneck/benchmark
bottleneck/slow
bottleneck/src
bottleneck/src/auto_pyx
bottleneck/src/template
bottleneck/tests
move
nonreduce
nonreduce_axis
reduce
```

and is clearly broken.

I'm not sure, but I think the problem is that the `PACKAGES` variable in `setup.py` is not what should be passed to the `packages=` keyword argument.

items.title: Robustness of `move_std`
items.body:
The algorithm used by `move_std` is prone to numerical errors. A while back I rewrote the implementation of the equivalent function in Pandas to use what some call [Welford's method](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithms_for_calculating_variance#Online_algorithm), a one pass stable algorithm, see [here](https://github.com/pydata/pandas/pull/6817) for the relevant PR. I took some timings on the Pandas code, and it resulted in a 25% slowdown.

Would you like to see something like that implemented for bottleneck?

items.title: Rewrite of bottleneck internals
items.body:
Here's a proposal for a rewrite of the bottlleneck internals. The main goals:
- Easier to add functions to bottleneck
- Easier to maintain
- Less C code

The easiest way to explain what I have in mind is with an example written in pure python:

```
import numpy as np


def nanmean_2d_float64_axis0(a):
    algo = Nanmean()
    return reduce_2d_float64_axis0(a, algo)


def reduce_2d_float64_axis0(a, algo):
    n0, n1 = a.shape
    y = np.empty(n1)
    for j in range(n1):
        algo.clear()
        for i in range(n0):
            ai = a[i, j]
            algo.append(ai)
        y[j] = algo.calc()
    return y


class Nanmean(object):

    def __init__(self):
        self.count = 0
        self.asum = 0

    def append(self, ai):
        if ai == ai:
            self.asum += ai
            self.count += 1

    def calc(self):
        if self.count > 0:
            return self.asum / self.count
        else:
            return np.nan

    def clear(self):
        self.asum = 0
        self.count = 0
```

Note that:
- `nanmean_2d_float64_axis0` keeps the same name and signature as in the current code.
- `reduce_2d_float64_axis0` can be (re)used with any reduce function such as
  nansum or median.
- The algo, here `Nanmean`, only has to be written for the 1d case.

To add a new function, the user only has to think about the 1d case and then write the algo class (I've never written a cython class but I assume it can be done). Bottleneck should take care of the rest.

A similar setup would be used for moving window functions.

I can't picture what all this would look like in practice, but just wanted to record the thought.
